name: Yami
subtitle: Goddess of the Yamuna River and Sister of Death
description: Yami (Sanskrit: 'twin') is the Hindu goddess of the sacred Yamuna River and the twin sister of Yama, the god of death and the underworld. According to the Rig Veda, Yami and Yama were the first mortals, born from the sun god Vivasvat (Surya) and his wife Saranyu (or Samjna), making them solar deities connected to both life and death. In one of Hinduism's most poignant mythological narratives, Yami desperately grieved for her deceased brother Yama, weeping so inconsolably that the gods created night to give her respite from her sorrow - before night's creation, it was eternal day, and Yami's grief knew no boundary of time. Her tears of mourning became the sacred Yamuna River, which flows through India alongside the Ganges as one of Hinduism's holiest waterways. While Yama became lord of the dead, Yami embodies the principle of sisterly love, the life-giving power of rivers, and the emotional depth of grief transformed into blessing. She represents the flowing continuity of life even in the face of death, her waters purifying pilgrims and sustaining civilizations.

sections.Origins: Yami's origins in the Rig Veda establish her as one of humanity's first beings. She and her twin brother Yama were born to Vivasvat (the sun god, an aspect of Surya) and Saranyu, daughter of the divine craftsman Tvashtar. Their birth as twins from the sun connects them to solar mythology and the cosmic cycle of day and night, life and death. The Rig Veda contains a famous dialogue hymn (10.10) in which Yami attempts to persuade Yama to become her consort and produce offspring to populate the world, but Yama refuses, establishing the fundamental incest taboo. This refusal, while preventing their union, affirmed moral law even among the first humans. Yama's subsequent death made him the first mortal to die, and thus lord of the dead.
sections.Mythology: The central myth of Yami concerns her inconsolable grief after Yama's death. In the Bhagavata Purana and other texts, Yami wept continuously for her brother, unable to find peace or cessation from her sorrow. Because time was undifferentiated and it was always day, her grief extended endlessly without the relief of night and sleep. The gods, moved by compassion, created night so that days would pass and time would heal her wounds. With each new dawn, Yami would say 'Today, my brother died,' and the passage of days gradually softened her grief. Her endless tears became the Yamuna River, transforming personal sorrow into a source of life and purification for all beings. This myth explains both the creation of night and the sacred nature of the Yamuna.
sections.Role: In Hindu religious practice, Yami is worshipped as the Yamuna River itself, one of the seven sacred rivers of India. The Yamuna joins the Ganges at Prayagraj (Allahabad) at the sacred confluence (Sangam), one of Hinduism's most important pilgrimage sites. Bathing in the Yamuna is believed to cleanse sins and connect devotees to the goddess's nurturing, life-sustaining power. Yami is particularly associated with sisterly love and the sister-brother bond, celebrated during the festival of Bhai Dooj (or Yama Dwitiya), when sisters pray for their brothers' welfare and long life, explicitly invoking the Yama-Yami relationship. She represents the emotional and nurturing aspects of divinity, complementing her brother's stern justice.
sections.Legacy: Yami's legacy manifests physically in the Yamuna River, which flows over 1,300 kilometers through northern India, sustaining millions and watering some of India's most sacred sites including Mathura, the birthplace of Krishna. The river's association with Krishna's childhood adventures adds layers to Yami's significance - she became the beloved playground of the divine child. Bhai Dooj remains one of India's most widely celebrated festivals, directly commemorating Yami's love for Yama. Her transformation of grief into life-giving water offers a profound theological statement about suffering's potential to become blessing. In comparative mythology, the Yama-Yami pair finds parallels in the Norse Ymir (first being), the Avestan Yima (first king), and other Indo-European first-ancestor traditions.
